Logical Operators (Gateways)
In business processes (BP),
gateways/logical operators
are used to record divergences and convergences of the BP workflow
and determine the progress of the route object. Thus, this item implies branching, splitting, merging and connecting the routes of the object(s) in the BP of the System.
On the BP flow chart, the gateway is represented as a diamond (by default, the System will display an
Exclusive gateway
, which is described below):
The type of gateway determines its specificity. To choose a gateway type, click the
button in its menu: a list of types will open.
Gateways of each type affect both inbound and outbound flows. The gateway types are:
– Exclusive gateway (the OR operator, exclusive gateway):
if the operator is used to branch the BP, the workflow is directed only on one outgoing branch (depending on the conditions)
if the operator is used for synchronization, it waits for at least one incoming branch to complete and activates the outbound flow
– Parallel gateway (the AND operator, parallel gateway):
if the operator is used for branching, it splits one control flow into several parallel ones. All outgoing branches are activated at the same time
if the operator is used for synchronization, it waits for all incoming branches to complete and then activates the outbound flow
– Inclusive gateway (the inclusive OR operator, inclusive gateway):
it activates one or more outgoing branches if branching is performed
if the operator is used for synchronization, it waits for one incoming branch to complete and activates the outbound flow
– Complex gateway has several conditions, depending on meeting which the outgoing branches are activated. Conditions are set for transitions (in the item settings window) coming out of this operator
– Event-based gateway (the exclusive OR operator) directs the control flow only to the outgoing branch on which the event occurred first. Only events or message handler actions can follow the operator of this type
To configure the gateway of the selected type, you need to:
1. Drag the item to the workspace of the custom BP. For more information, refer to
Setting up business process flow charts
.
2. Save the business flow chart generated.
3. Click
on the item’s action bar. The System will display the settings profile.
The outbound flows (flow) will be defined automatically
after saving the BP flow chart. The following gateway parameters are defined automatically, where:
Setting
Purpose
Name
Displaying the setting name. It is formed automatically, borrowed from the name of the connector used (for more information, refer to
Control Flows Connector
).
Condition type
The display of the gateway type is generated automatically.
Identifier
The display of the BP item identifier is generated automatically.
Setting up outbound transitions
The outbound transitions are formed automatically according to the custom flow chart. The field is editable.
For example, when considering the business process which takes into account the early repayment of the loan, the gateway branches the flow chart into:
on-time loan repayment
early repayment
At the same time, the System allows you to create (edit) outbound flows. The first transition is taken into account by default in case of on-time loan repayment. The second transition – the
early repayment
– is configured by the analyst. Here, you need to specify the algorithm (condition) to define the route of the Client’s Request (Application for decision-making) in case of early repayment of the loan.
For example, you can edit the visual settings in the profile of any object (for more information, refer to
Configuring the visual
).
The transition condition is specified by the algorithm (condition) to define the route of the Client’s Request (application) for early repayment of the loan:
In other words, if you specify the
Early repayment
option, the route object will be directed to the conditional transition of the business process.
